comments.commentBody: Keep it up, Rijk, and we'll be calling you D. Feelgood!

Jerrold,

I was simply describing what was in the movie. You can see it for yourself (only 2:24 long):

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xTq20prt0K8

Enjoy!

Well try repealing the Second Amendment; it want be easy. You also will not find it so easy to find judges to nullify the recent Supreme Court decision on the Second Amendment, it was well reasoned and conforms with some scholarly commentary on the subject so it isn't so outrageous as to invite being overruled anytime soon. As to the electorate, according to recent polls the majority do not favor new gun laws. You are going to be waiting around a very long time for your predicted political revolution.

This is a perfect example why there is no dialog in this country between gun owners and people concerned about massacres committed with guns. There is just too much support for gun ownership in this country to get anywhere without dialog.

Mayor Bloomberg's prestige doesn't even make it across the Hudson River. He is famous in his own mind.

The senators and representatives already know there is nothing to gain from gun control - the voters don't want it and the NRA will bankroll their opponent at the next election. That's what you get in a democracy; if the majority of the people don't want something and they put their money where their mouth is they win. You need to talk to gun rights advocates not demonize them.

There is nothing more angelic than first graders and nothing more horrible than what happened in Newtown, but to use them their names or picture for political purposes goes beyond bad taste in this culture.

Meet Denny Dimwit.  When I was growing up in Chicago, I read the comics in the Tribune every Sunday.  One strip was called Winnie Winkle but on Sunday it was about Denny Dimwit.  His name says it all.  In the only strip I remember there was a man offering Denny his choice of taking a dime or a nickel.  Denny kept taking a nickel and the man was so amused by Denny’s stupidity that he kept offering him the same choice.  The man thought Denny took the nickel because  it was bigger.  In the last scene the man had left and Denny’s friend asked him why he kept talking a nickel when the dime was worth twice as much.  Denny replied that if he took the dime the man would not have offered him the choice again.  Some of the answers in this puzzle made me feel like a dimwit.

Find some qualified experts not sponsored by gun money and cite their research in order to be more persuasive in your argument.

Restricting the use by the general population of certain types of firearms and ammunition doesn't mean that the police have to use gummie bears. Get serious.

Find some qualified experts not sponsored by gun money and cite their research in order to be more persuasive in your argument.

Restricting the use by the general population of certain types of firearms and ammunition doesn't mean that the police have to use gummie bears. Get serious.

Tell me how you will convince criminals to follow these stricter law! It already illegal for a person who has committed a felony to possess a firearm yet this law has no effect.

Russia, Britain and China with their strict laws, still have these issues.

People have been killing people since we arrived on this planet. Tim McVeigh didn't use a gun, nor did the infamous 9/11 hijackers.

In my small town it takes 15 20 minutes for a police response, I know, for a very intoxicated individual whom had the wrong address was intent on entering my home. Something about the sound of a pump action benelli changed his mind, even drunk!
Because the armed citizen is prevented from having their firearms on them due to "gun free zones". They are actually following the law.
China invented ancient firearms. They are your ancient gun Gods

Some measure of gun control is obviously needed. There is no real reason for citizens to own military assault weapons, and stricter requirements need to be placed on handguns, as the primary purpose of a handgun is to
shoot people A good start would be to have federal legislation regulating gun shows, closing this loophole exploiting our current inadequate gun control system. The American public is highly armed, yet only rarely does an armed citizen stop one of these massacres.
Mr. Riley, YOU are the type of person who should NEVER be allowed a firearm.  Paranoia and bullets are not a healthy recipe for the rest of us to taste.
So to protect ourselves against a *theoretical* threat, we should ignore a clear and present threat killing our family members and neighbors RIGHT NOW.

Tyrants back then don't have heavier weapons than guns on land. Now they do. Using just guns against such governments are laughable. Syrian rebels wouldn't last this long if Arabic and Western nations didn't provide them with heavier weapons since they all only had guns in the beginning.
We must protect the right to own firearms in order to prevent the U.S.A from degenerating into a totalitarian state.  The Tyrant simply cannot tyrannize a populace as armed as is the U.S. population.
"Gun safety" sounds like a contradiction in terms to me. The purpose of a gun is to put other people's lives in danger, isn't it?

Seems like you also forgot your facts--or maybe you just fell for the NRA's incorrect tropes that they have regurgitated for years to the point where people like your start citing incorrect information. There is NO country on the planet that has anywhere near as many guns per capita as in America. There are countries with roughly half the guns per capita that America does and yes, even number 2 (with a bullet), Yemen, has less gun deaths per year than America.
http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2012/12/15/what-makes-...

I doubt that is true. For decades, I would hear about Israel and Switzerland, where, supposedly, gun ownership is rather universal (well, in Israel, a couple of groups notably excluded...). And it isn't so, see:
http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2012/12/14/mythbusting-i...
For that reason, I would be surprised were this true. And the assault weapons ban we had during the Clinton years did not destroy the country; G W Bush merely let its sunset provision take effect, and chose not to renew it. I agree that `we should be able to do better', but renewing the assault weapons bans would be a start, and would put us in the frame of mind to thinks of ways of making even yet better.

A wise Congresswoman (sorry, I forget her name) said on MSNBC that we have to talk of gun safety, not of gun control. If this becomes a battle about taking away people's guns, we will not make headway.

There are countries with as many per capita guns, but much less gun violence. So we should be able to do better.

Rijkstra,

One reco of your response is mine, not just a check mark that someone read it.

You are correct, it is a little hard to find the latest. However, it's a toss-up which is more desirable: the time stamp or the subject thread. I have gotten used to the subject thread method here and I like it.

If you reorder replies within threads placing the newest one on top like the main posts, a reply to a reply would appear on top of the one to which it referred, the newest one often leapfrogging multiple others. That would be clumsy.

In Rex's blog there are no threads, comments are arranged by time stamp only. A snap, right? But too many posts start with @ [name], many of them having multiple paragraphs each starting with a different @ [name], in which you don't know what they are talking about until you find all those [names] and also read their comments. Talk about clumsy.

But I shan't go on.

I think suggesting further "improvements" to the blog is inviting disaster. Let them get what they've got working right again first.

As to your point, I red the blog for the wordplay and conversation, not as a reco contest. I use the reco button for comments I find particularly entertaining or salient, but not as a guide to reading (re-reading actually). I find it pretty easy to skim through and find something that I haven't read yet.

I think that the bigger blogs with more elaborate tracking systems usually have threads that span days or even weeks. Here, every day is new.

Laz,

No way do I propose reordering replies within threads, just threads within the blog for the "Newest" sort only. If the cream rises to the top we won't have to search the entire blog for all the latest replies.

After easily finding the last reply I hadn't read buried among 100+ posts yesterday, I decided to go on another reco rampage.  This technique for finding unread replies really seems to work well.  So if you only got one reco, you really only received my mark!
You're right - this should not be a part of some political agenda.  It should be a part of every rational citizen's  national agenda.
You're right - this should not be a part of some political agenda.  It should be a part of every rational citizen's  national agenda.

"Prints of Peas" doesn't pass the ear test.

Prints of Piece - Pictures of my new gun.

@AdamS No need to take a dig at Pakistan. Pakistan has done a pretty good job of preserving its historical sites, which include the neolithic site of Mehrgarh (7000 BC), the Indus Valley sites of Mohenjo-daro and Harappa (3300-2200 BC), and the Buddhist sites of Taxila (500 BC to 100 AD) and Takht-i-Bahi (100 AD). There is nothing like these sites in India, both in provenance and abundance of artifacts.

Also, Pakistan has allowed the best international archaeologists to work at these sites, which ensures that they receive state of the art attention. India, on the other hand, has not. The Archaeological Survey of India, which until the 1960s had some excellent archaeologists and epigraphists, is now a second-rate institution.

Stu -- The Biafran Civil War in Nigeria in the late 60s was just such an attempt to separate provinces. It was as awful a war as ever fought. The US was badly conflicted over what to do there, debated it intensively, and was horrified by the suffering. We remain just as conflicted still, in Congo as in Nigeria. We have had no answers to this problem since then.

The many separatist wars in Congo are just like Biafra, replayed over and over since the original Congo Crisis of independence starting in 1960. The UN Sec Gen Dag Hammarskjöld was killed, likely assassinated for his efforts, while trying to help settle that. There have been efforts made.

The one consistent thing in all this immense suffering is that the governments can and do always hold their territory, even though they cannot or will not govern that territory. The people are essentially abandoned.

There is nothing good to say about these governments. If they were just gone, all could hardly be worse than it is. But that is not what has ever happened, nor does that set of circumstances seem likely to change in any way fundamental enough to produce a different result.

The US needs to re-visit its thinking from the policies that guided us in Biafra and the Congo Crisis in the 60s.

We can and ought to make some fundamental changes in the circumstances that allow these useless and evil governments to hang on. These governments are too weak to survive an outside policy with real direction.

Stu...what do you mean by, "The nation will probably have to implode in order that its contingent provinces have any chance of succeeding on their own."  Do you mean that millions of death, rapes, killing, human rights violations, must continue in Congo? How can you be heartless when children are enrolled in rebels armies created and financed by Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize Eastern, and plunder natural resources in Congo. What do you know about Congo and who told you that one of the determinants for developing a country is to slice it. Why don't we slice China, Canada, India or Russia...? Slicing a country ha never figure among the determinants of the development or economic growth. However, the governance and peace are strongly correlated with development. Today even if we slice Congo, and leave the Rwanda creating and arming rebel groups in the new sliced Congo, do you think that your new sliced Congo will have peace and development. The problem of Congo is known...You need to read the UN report of experts...Rwanda is pointed as responsible of creating, arming, training, recruiting, and financing rebels groups in order to destabilize the Congo and plunder its natural resources...Susan Rice has paid today with the world and America's disgrace and shame for ignoring and falsifying UN reports according to New York Times. The UN has already given us the diagnostic, the sources of conflicts in the Eastern Congo is Rwanda...Stop and Condemn Kagame and Congo will be healed.

Do you mean that millions of death, rapes, killing, human rights violations, must continue in Congo? How can you be heartless when children are enrolled in rebels armies created and financed by Rwanda and Uganda to destabilize Eastern, and plunder natural resources in Congo. Today even if we slice Congo, and leave the Rwanda creating and arming rebel groups in the new sliced Congo, do you think that your new sliced Congo will have peace and development. The problem of Congo is known...You need to read the UN report of experts...Rwanda is pointed as responsible of creating, arming, training, recruiting, and financing rebels groups in order to destabilize the Congo and plunder its natural resources...Susan Rice has paid today with the world and America's disgrace and shame for ignoring and falsifying UN reports according to New York Times. The UN has already given us the diagnostic, the sources of conflicts in the Eastern Congo is Rwanda...Stop and Condemn Kagame and Congo will be healed.

Apparently mineral wealth can't compete with petroleum when it comes to getting the rest of the world's attention.  Congo is obviously too big to govern, especially considering that Kinshasha's location in the extreme western part of the country makes it about a week's journey from Goma.  The nation will probably have to implode in order that its contingent provinces have any chance of succeeding on their own.

Rijkstra,

If we all did that, every single comment would have the identical number of recos, in which case the idea and the purpose of the RECOMMEND button becomes useless.

Maybe we should lobby the emus to add an "unread" and "read" option. Can you imagine that nightmare?

If every single email you receive is marked URGENT, it is guaranteed that you will miss the few that were truly urgent.

Wonderful, Laszlo.

Special kudos to CAMEA.

Agree with you on THREW THE REIGN because it's based the original phrase doesn't really stand on its own.

I can't believe it, Laszlo. You said you wanted to get ORFF, and you DINT....So hears sum (not the well-known 1st, but the 2nd).

http://www.youtube.com/watch?NR=1&feature=endscreen&v=0Nn3PcESF7w

You had me laughing throughout...Soooo good!

Once I was HAILING a taxi in Italy. Most DINT stop, but when one finally pulled over, I got in and asked the hack: "KENAI get to the next town AMEER 4 kilometers from HRE?" He answered with a thick accent: "Veerto? ALIOTO, LIETO, TIETO Orvieto?" I said: "Stop the cab, I want to get ORFF."

The ASKERS and the BLESSERS reside in the upscale area of town, each family living in a stately MANSE.

After walking around the Las Vegas Convention Center trying to sell soundboard FADERS for eight hours, I like to sit back ASLANT in a comfy chair in my hotel suite, place AFOOT in ASOAK of warm water, then without breaking ASWEAT, I place my other foot right next the first one. OAHU, that feels soooo good!

CAMEA: Walk-on appearance of female celebrity.
NODOSE: Skip your medication.
COHOS: Multiple Santa outpourings of equal value.

Ugliest crossing of the year: TOTIE x TIETO.

Otherwise a fun puzzle. Loved the puns but THREW THE REIGN did not work as well as the others. Thanks, Matt Ginsberg.

All very well. But what about mentally sane people with guns who develop mental conditions later? Subject all gun owners to regular compulsory tests to check their mental stability? Sounds not too feasible to me.

Smart words, indeed. In many, many of these cases the issue is NOT guns, but schizophrenics that should have been institutionalized. The conversation that we need to have is around reversing the de-institutionalization trends that started in earnest in the '60's and '70's.

There have been plenty of red flags for the killers in Newtown, Aurora, Arizona, etc. These people all have serious mental issues that were recognized well before they killed indiscriminately.

Cf. Clayton Cramer, "Madness, Deinstitutionalization & Murder" May 2012.

Um, if you read the story, he got it from his mom, who he shot in the face. Are you advocating prosecuting her, as the gun provider? Are you advocating suing her estate? He murdered her, and took her guns. Who is the responsible party?

"I've done my best to avoid becoming well informed about the current tragedy, so I don't know if there was any diagnosis of psychosis, but why not start there anyway?"

Why are you trumpeting the fact you just stick your fingers in your ears and say "La la la/"

How pathetic.

I'm hoping that rather than doing the usual reactive outrage/fear thing, that calmer minds will try to come up with one specific aspect that's particularly troubling and work to do something about it. My choice starts with keeping guns out of the hands of those too impaired, at least some of the time, to safely use one - those with mental impairments - dementia, psychosis, and obvious impulse control disorders. How sort out who/when/how long free of symptoms, etc? There are some laws in this area already. Knowledgeable people can discuss this reasonably.

I've done my best to avoid becoming well informed about the current tragedy, so I don't know if there was any diagnosis of psychosis, but why not start there anyway? How do we improve keeping firearms away from people who have active psychosis - at least some kinds of psychosis, etc?

Start small. Do it carefully. Evaluate. Expand as warranted.

A black mark! i didn't intend to be Rijk'd over the kohls...

Try these:

Stain the coarse -- The Scarlet Letter
Four get me nought -- Terrible odds
Sum daze -- two plus two equals five

It is not widespread distribution of firearms that keeps us from living in a totalitarian state, but rather the widespread respect for the democratic process that we are taught at the earliest age. What is more concerning is the fear mongering attitude, often accompanied by conspiracy theory advocacy, exhibited by Mr. Riley.

These false choices - a populace armed without reservation or tyranny - must be recognized for what they are. The people of the US must now stand up and demand a saner approach to firearm regulation.

You know, I am sick of hearing my thoughts and prayers are with you.
How about some action, how about adopting real solutions to gun violence.
How about taxing arms and ammo like we tax alcohol, make it to expensive to have 10 or 12 guns, and thousands of rounds of ammo.

How about passing laws that make the owners, sellers, makers responsible for the guns they own and sell.
How about making gun owners carry liability insurance for the arms they keep in their home.

I for one am sick of listening to prayers and best wishes, its time to act and start putting a stop to the deaths.
Rarely? How about never.
Chris, if you to wield a gun against any federal law enforcement official in your own crusade against tyranny, I can assure you that nothing could get you killed faster.

I own a Smith and Wesson 22a pistol. It's primary purpose is to put tiny holes in pieces of paper in tight groups in the center of the target out to and past a distance of fifty yards while aiming unsupported. Using China as an example of anything to emulate brings up resistance in me.
